benefits.title: Evaluation and clinical comparison studies on liposomal and non-liposomal ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and their enhanced bioavailability
benefits.summary: Liposomal vitamin C is 1.77 times more bioavailable than non-liposomal vitamin C, with higher values of Cmax, AUC0–t, and AUC0-Î± related to non-liposomal vitamin C.

benefits.title: Vitamin C and Immune Function
benefits.summary: Liposomal Vitamin C contributes to immune defense by supporting various cellular functions of both the innate and adaptive immune system, enhancing cellular functions and preventing and treating infections.

benefits.title: Interaction of Ascorbate and α‐Tocopherol
benefits.summary: Liposomal vitamin C acts as a synergist with vitamin E, protecting lipids, proteins, and membranes from oxidative damage.
benefits.journal: Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences

benefits.title: Individual and combined antioxidant effects of seven phenolic agents in human erythrocyte membrane ghosts and phosphatidylcholine liposome systems: importance of the partition coefficient.
benefits.summary: Combining caffeic acid, catechin, and epicatechin with alpha-tocopherol, beta-carotene, and vitamin C may provide stronger protective benefits against lipid oxidation, potentially helping with oxidation-related diseases prevention.
benefits.journal: Journal of agricultural and food chemistry

benefits.title: Vitamin C and Heart Health: A Review Based on Findings from Epidemiologic Studies
benefits.summary: Vitamin C may slightly improve endothelial function and lipid profiles in some groups, especially those with low plasma vitamin C levels.

benefits.title: Vitamin C–squalene bioconjugate promotes epidermal thickening and collagen production in human skin
benefits.summary: Liposomal Vitamin C-squalene bioconjugate significantly increases epidermal thickness and favors collagen III production in human skin after application for 10 days.

benefits.title: Enhanced Resorption of Liposomal Packed Vitamin C Monitored by Ultrasound
benefits.summary: Liposomal vitamin C can enhance intestinal vitamin C resorption, potentially improving resistance to infections involving the immune system.

benefits.title: Polarization of Tumor-Associated Macrophages Promoted by Vitamin C-Loaded Liposomes for Cancer Immunotherapy.
benefits.summary: Vitamin C-loaded liposomes can induce oxidative toxicity and promote the infiltration of activating cytotoxic T lymphocytes in the tumor microenvironment, enhancing immune response and process in cancer treatment.

benefits.title: Formulation of vitamin C encapsulation in marine phospholipids nanoliposomes: Characterization and stability evaluation during long term storage
benefits.summary: Liposomal vitamin C can protect it during long-term storage and maintain its antioxidant activity.

benefits.title: Liposomal-encapsulated Ascorbic Acid: Influence on Vitamin C Bioavailability and Capacity to Protect Against Ischemia–Reperfusion Injury
benefits.summary: Oral delivery of vitamin C encapsulated in liposomes provides protection from ischemia-reperfusion-mediated oxidative stress similar to unencapsulated oral and intravenous administrations.

side effects.title: Oral administration of vitamin C decreases muscle mitochondrial biogenesis and hampers training-induced adaptations in endurance performance.
side effects.summary: Vitamin C supplementation decreases training efficiency by preventing some cellular adaptations to exercise.
side effects.journal: The American journal of clinical nutrition

side effects.title: The influence of large doses of vitamin C on psychological functioning
side effects.summary: Large doses of vitamin C can lead to decreased reaction times and psychomotor coordination.

side effects.title: Vitamin C antioxidant effects in hippocampus of adult Wistar rats after seizures and status epilepticus induced by pilocarpine
side effects.summary: Vitamin C can increase latency to first seizure and decrease mortality rate in adult rats after seizures and status epilepticus induced by pilocarpine.

side effects.title: Vitamin C and cancer chemoprevention: reappraisal.
side effects.summary: A moderate daily dose of supplementary vitamin C (200 mg) induces the formation of genotoxins, resulting in DNA damage and initiation of carcinogenesis.
side effects.journal: The American journal of clinical nutrition

side effects.title: Liposomal-encapsulated Ascorbic Acid: Influence on Vitamin C Bioavailability and Capacity to Protect Against Ischemia–Reperfusion Injury
side effects.summary: Oral delivery of vitamin C encapsulated in liposomes provides protection from ischemia-reperfusion-mediated oxidative stress similar to unencapsulated oral and intravenous administrations.

side effects.title: Alleviation of genotoxic effects of cyclophosphamide using encapsulation into liposomes in the absence or presence of vitamin C.
side effects.summary: Liposomal vitamin C can diminish the potential side effects of cyclophosphamide by acting as an antioxidant and reducing oxidative stress.

side effects.title: The effect of pharmacological supplementation with vitamin C on low-density lipoprotein oxidation.
side effects.summary: Vitamin C supplementation may have a protective role against lipid peroxidation by decreasing plasma MDA levels and enhancing vitamin E and GSH status.

side effects.title: Enhanced Resorption of Liposomal Packed Vitamin C Monitored by Ultrasound
side effects.summary: Liposomal vitamin C can enhance intestinal vitamin C resorption, potentially improving resistance to infections involving the immune system.

side effects.title: Effects of liposomal nasal spray with vitamins A and E on allergic rhinitis
side effects.summary: Liposomal nasal spray improves nasal symptoms of allergic rhinitis with limited side effects.

dosage.title: Effects of vitamin C supplementation on antioxidants and lipid peroxidation markers in elderly subjects with type 2 diabetes.
dosage.summary: 0.5 and 1g of vitamin C per day significantly increased cellular reduced glutathione levels and vitamin E content of LDL in elderly patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

dosage.title: Liposomal-encapsulated Ascorbic Acid: Influence on Vitamin C Bioavailability and Capacity to Protect Against Ischemia–Reperfusion Injury
dosage.summary: Oral delivery of 4g of vitamin C encapsulated in liposomes provides protection from ischemia-reperfusion-mediated oxidative stress similar to unencapsulated oral and intravenous administrations.

dosage.title: Does short-term vitamin C reduce cardiovascular risk in type 2 diabetes?
dosage.summary: Vitamin C at dosages of 250, 500, and 1,000 mg per day did not show significant effects on lipid parameters or oxidative stress, inflammation, or hypercoagulability in type 2 diabetes.
dosage.journal: Endocrine practice : official journal of the American College of Endocrinology and the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists

dosage.title: Vitamin C antioxidant effects in hippocampus of adult Wistar rats after seizures and status epilepticus induced by pilocarpine
dosage.summary: Vitamin C pretreatment at 250 mg/kg, i.p., 30 minutes before pilocarpine administration increased latency to first seizure and decreased mortality rate in adult rats.

dosage.title: Consumption of high-dose vitamin C (1250 mg per day) enhances functional and structural properties of serum lipoprotein to improve anti-oxidant, anti-atherosclerotic, and anti-aging effects via regulation of anti-inflammatory microRNA.
dosage.summary: High-dose vitamin C (1250 mg per day) enhances serum lipoprotein properties, improving anti-oxidant, anti-atherosclerotic, and anti-aging effects.

dosage.title: Новые технологии в лечении железодефицитной анемии
dosage.summary: A combination of liposomal iron and vitamin C at a daily dosage of 30 (1 capsule) and 60 mg (2 capsules) showed similar results to bivalent iron and vitamin C at higher dosages.

dosage.title: Criteria and recommendations for vitamin C intake.
dosage.summary: A recent study suggests that a vitamin C intake of 100 mg-200 mg/day is needed, which is two to threefold greater than the current Recommended Dietary Allowance.

dosage.title: Effect of vitamin C on ambulatory blood pressure and plasma lipids in older persons
dosage.summary: Oral vitamin C supplements (500 mg daily) showed a small but significant fall in systolic blood pressure in older adults.

dosage.title: A new recommended dietary allowance of vitamin C for healthy young women
dosage.summary: The recommended dietary allowance of vitamin C for young women should be increased to 90 mg daily.
dosage.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

dosage.title: Vitamin C pharmacokinetics in healthy volunteers: evidence for a recommended dietary allowance.
dosage.summary: The current RDA of 60 mg daily should be increased to 200 mg daily, which can be obtained from fruits and vegetables.
dosage.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
